_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Introduction

A Risk Management Program has been implemented at Arkema's Calvert City production facility for the reduction of accidental releases of hazardous materials.  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) summarizes the management, administrative, procedural, and technological controls that work together to minimize the risk to the community of hazardous chemical releases.  



Arkema Policies for Health, Environment, and Safety

Arkema's commitment to health, environment, and safety (HES) starts with the CEO.  Senior management routinely dedicates time to a review of HES matters.  This emphasis on safety is carried through to the facility level, where the plant manager, the HES manager, and the Plant Safety Committee regularly review safety performance, take corrective actions, and strive for continuous improvement.  The success of Arkema's HES programs is also reflected by a strong commitment to safety by employees and contractors.



Facility Identification and Regulated Substances in Covered Processes

The Arkema Calvert City facility, a wholly-owned contiguous facility of Arkema Inc., is located at 4444 Industrial Parkway, Calvert City, Kentucky.  As such it is considered a single stationary source requiring one RMP submittal.  The facility manufactures refrigerants by continuous chemical reaction and purification processes in four operating units (designated as K-97, K-98, F-134a and monomer).  In addition, the company operates an AHF storage facility and a hazardous waste incinerator.  Certain substances used and produced within these operating units are regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule.  The substances that are present at or above the minimum threshold for RMP applicability are hydrogen fluoride (HF), chlorine, aqueous hydrogen chloride (HCl), and vinylidene fluoride (R-1132a).  HF and chlorine are used as raw materials in the production of refrigerant gases.  Aqueous hydrogen chloride is a co-product of the refrigera

nt process, producing a 36% HCl solution.  Vinylidene fluoride is both a product for off-site sale and a reactant in a polymerization process.



Normal production of aqueous HCl results in a solution below the 37% threshold concentration for coverage under the RMP rule.  It is possible, due to brief process upsets, for a production unit to produce hydrochloric acid at a strength of greater than 37% and collect it in a short-term storage (shift) tank.  Because the plant HCl production specification requires acid strengths between 35.21 and 36.9%, plant procedures require that any off-specification acid will be disposed of or diluted to meet specifications before packaging.  As such, aqueous HCl will be included as predictive reporting.



HF is shipped to the facility in railcars.  In addition to the regular number of cars held in the plant, there are situations such as curtailed production or supply chain issues which could result in an additional number of cars in the facility, increasing the HF inventory.  As a precautionary notification, Arkema has included in this submittal a quantity equal to the maximum number of railcars that could be expected on site at any one time.



Liquid chlorine is transferred from a railcar to a storage tank in the F-134a area, where it is distributed throughout the plant.  Normally a railcar is ordered when one car is unloaded, using a production forecast to determine when a car should be needed.  It is possible, however, that a production interruption or business disruption could allow a car to arrive in the plant before the storage tank has enough room to allow the car to be unloaded, increasing the plant's overall inventory.  This submittal predicatively assumes that the storage tank contains chlorine above the normal unloading weight and a full railcar is onsite.



Monomer is loaded into intermodal containers called tube trailers for over-the-road shipping.  The reported inventory of VF2 includes a number of these trailers on

aintenance, and emergency response personnel are a key element in reducing and mitigating accidents.



General, yet extensive, measures through equipment and piping design and construction are in place that would prevent the developed scenarios for HF, aqueous HCl, chlorine, and vinylidene fluoride.  These measures include:

- Storage tanks are pressure vessels designed and constructed in accordance with American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) pressure vessel standards using industry-standard materials of construction.  Furthermore, design specifications incorporate Zone 3 earthquake standards.

- As part of the mechanical integrity program, pressure vessels and atmospheric storage tanks are inspected and tested according to the American Petroleum Institute Standard 510 and Standard 653, respectively.

- The risk of overfilling is addressed by high level alarms and interlocks.

- The risk of over-pressure is prevented by a system of interlocks, pressure relief valves and vent headers.

- Tanks are generally located in areas where no overhead construction is allowed. Equipment is located to prevent impact to a tank.

- Access to the facility is restricted through security barriers and trained security personnel, thereby minimizing the risk to the tanks from vehicular damage or sabotage.

-Rail stops (or wheel chocks) to prevent movement of the car.



Also, there are certain chemical-specific measures in addition to these general measures:

- Daily (HF) or per use (chlorine) hose inspections and tests with annual replacement.

- Automatic valves in the pump discharge lines that closes automatically when the pumps shut down to prevent backflow from the tanks (HF).

- Extra heavy-walled vessels (HF and chlorine).

- Materials of construction designed for specific service.



Five-Year Accident History

There have been no releases of any regulated chemical in the past five years that have had an adverse off-site impact on the community or environment or that me

et the RMP reporting requirements with respect to injuries.  Arkema realizes that the community may also be interested in smaller releases of regulated chemicals that do not meet EPA criteria for the five-year accident history.  We have been diligent in reporting releases of hazardous materials and in internally investigating and correcting the causes of such releases.



Integrated Contingency and Response Plan

This Integrated Contingency and Response Plan (ICRP) has been prepared to comply with the requirements of Federal and Kentucky regulations and corporate policies and procedures concerning contingency, preparedness, emergency action plans, and internal and external incident reporting.  The ICRP was developed in cooperation with civil authorities (local emergency planning committee, sheriff's department, police, fire, emergency medical, etc.) and was coordinated with the community emergency response plan developed under 42 U.S.C. 11003.



The ICRP includes procedures for notifying civil authorities and the public in the event of an incident.  The ICRP also includes documentation of proper first-aid and medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures; procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection and testing; a description of the training program for all employees in relevant emergency response procedures; and procedures for review and update, as appropriate, of the ICRP to reflect changes at the facility, and to ensure that employees are informed of these changes.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety has been a part of the working culture at the facility for many years.  Chemical exposure risks to employees and the public have been minimized through ongoing internal risk reduction efforts as well as regulatory requirements.  The facility utilizes process hazard analyses and risk assessments to continuously improve process and personnel safety
